headline: Trading Day: Fed bets slip, Powell takes the stage
summary: U.S. stocks fell on Thursday and the dollar and Treasury yields rose, as solid factory data cast a bit more doubt on the Fed's readiness to lower interest rates next month.  All eyes are now firmly on Fed Chair Jerome Powell's Jackson Hole speech on Friday.  In my column today, I look at the apparent contradiction between record inflows into U.S. assets from abroad, and the 125 basis points of Fed rate cuts traders are expecting by the end of next year.

headline: Walmart outlook strong but risks remain, says portfolio manager
summary: STORY: Walmart's results on Thursday show U.S. consumers across the spectrum are still flocking to the retailer's stores despite economic headwinds, but shares dipped as the company's margins ebbed and inventory costs rose."Tariff related costs are being pushed onto the consumer," noted Carey, which he said is concerning."Lower income and middle income households are definitely starting to cut back," said Carey. "They're, in some cases within Walmart, trading down in terms of item quality from premium brand to name brand or even reducing the amount, the quantity of goods that they are consuming."

"They're, in some cases within Walmart, trading down in terms of item quality from premium brand to name brand or even reducing the amount, the quantity of goods that they are consuming."

headline: S&P 500 Falls for Fifth Day Ahead of Powell's Jackson Hole Speech
summary: The S&P 500 fell for a fifth day, as Wall Street trimmed bets on a September rate cut ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s speech at Jackson Hole on Friday.  The market benchmark dropped 0.4%; the S&P marked its longest losing streak since it fell the five days ending Jan. 2.  The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.3%, which brought its losing streak to three days, the longest it has fallen since the four days ending April 21.

The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.3%, which brought its losing streak to three days, the longest it has fallen since the four days ending April 21.

headline: Walmart results show consumer resilience; shares slip after rally
summary: STORY: Walmart raised its full-year sales and profit forecast on Thursday, citing strong demand from shoppers across all income levels who are turning to the retailer amid worries over rising costs.But shares fell as much as five and a half percent in Thursday morning trading as the world's largest retailer posted a second-quarter profit below estimates, its first earnings miss in more than three years.One analyst tells Reuters that estimates were too ambitious, and “The miss is not indicative of a slowdown in business fundamentals.”Walmart got a boost from a sharper online strategy as more customers relied on home deliveries. Its global e-commerce sales jumped 25% during the second quarter, and one-third of deliveries from stores took three hours or less.And even as weakening consumer sentiment due to tariffs has hit the bottom lines of some retail chains, Walmart's sales have remained resilient.Walmart CEO Doug McMillon said the impact of tariffs has been gradual enough to moderate any change in customer habits.But he noted on a call with analysts that costs will continue rising in the second half of the year.McMillion added that middle- and lower-income households are making noticeable adjustments in response to rising prices from tariffs, either by reducing the number of items in their baskets or by opting for more private-label brands. This shift has not been seen among higher-income households, which Walmart defines as those earning over $100,000 annually.

raw.headline: Walmart results show consumer resilience; shares slip after rally
raw.summary: STORY: Walmart raised its full-year sales and profit forecast on Thursday, citing strong demand from shoppers across all income levels who are turning to the retailer amid worries over rising costs.But shares fell as much as five and a half percent in Thursday morning trading as the world's largest retailer posted a second-quarter profit below estimates, its first earnings miss in more than three years.One analyst tells Reuters that estimates were too ambitious, and “The miss is not indicative of a slowdown in business fundamentals.”Walmart got a boost from a sharper online strategy as more customers relied on home deliveries. Its global e-commerce sales jumped 25% during the second quarter, and one-third of deliveries from stores took three hours or less.And even as weakening consumer sentiment due to tariffs has hit the bottom lines of some retail chains, Walmart's sales have remained resilient.Walmart CEO Doug McMillon said the impact of tariffs has been gradual enough to moderate any change in customer habits.But he noted on a call with analysts that costs will continue rising in the second half of the year.McMillion added that middle- and lower-income households are making noticeable adjustments in response to rising prices from tariffs, either by reducing the number of items in their baskets or by opting for more private-label brands. This shift has not been seen among higher-income households, which Walmart defines as those earning over $100,000 annually.

Walmart (WMT) is weighing on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The retailer reported Q2 earnings that disappointed traders. headline: Walmart Stock Falls Despite a Higher Earnings Forecast. Here’s Why.
summary: Walmart  raised its financial forecasts for the fiscal year, but its earnings fell slightly short of Wall Street’s expectations.  Walmart’s revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 1 rose 4.8% year over year to $177.4 billion, ahead of projections for $175.9 billion, according to FactSet.  Adjusted earnings per share were softer than Wall Street was projecting, coming in at 68 cents a share, compared with estimates for 73 cents.

raw.headline: Walmart Stock Falls Despite a Higher Earnings Forecast. Here’s Why.

Walmart’s revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 1 rose 4.8% year over year to $177.4 billion, ahead of projections for $175.9 billion, according to FactSet.  Adjusted earnings per share were softer than Wall Street was projecting, coming in at 68 cents a share, compared with estimates for 73 cents.

headline: Why Target can't keep up with Walmart's growth

headline: Wall St futures slip ahead of Walmart's results, Fed meet
summary: A sharp decline in technology stocks such as Nvidia, AMD, Palantir and Meta earlier this week signaled investor fears that the stocks, which have soared since April lows, are now overvalued, while Washington's growing interference in the sector has also raised alarms.  The selloff could also be a result of investors paring back their stock exposure during a traditionally rocky period for equities, according to the Stock Trader's Almanac.  "Equities could be more at risk of volatility amid this week's selloff in AI-related stocks on the back of renewed doubts about AI valuations," said Raffi Boyadjian, lead market analyst at brokerage XM.

raw.headline: Wall St futures slip ahead of Walmart's results, Fed meet
raw.summary: A sharp decline in technology stocks such as Nvidia, AMD, Palantir and Meta earlier this week signaled investor fears that the stocks, which have soared since April lows, are now overvalued, while Washington's growing interference in the sector has also raised alarms.  The selloff could also be a result of investors paring back their stock exposure during a traditionally rocky period for equities, according to the Stock Trader's Almanac.  "Equities could be more at risk of volatility amid this week's selloff in AI-related stocks on the back of renewed doubts about AI valuations," said Raffi Boyadjian, lead market analyst at brokerage XM.

headline: Stocks to Watch Thursday: Meta, Coty, Walmart, Novo Nordisk
summary: ? Meta Platforms (META): The Facebook parent has frozen hiring in its artificial-intelligence division after spending months scooping up researchers and engineers, The Wall Street Journal reported. ↘️ Coty (COTY): The beauty and scents company posted a unexpected quarterly adjusted loss of 5 cents a share.

headline: U.S. Stock Futures Steady Ahead of Fresh Economic Data
summary: U.S. stock futures were barely changed Thursday in Europe after lingering concerns about the AI-fueled boom knocked the tech sector again in Wednesday’s session. Fed Chair Jerome Powell, under pressure to cut rates in September, speaks at Jackson Hole on Friday.

headline: Retail Earnings Roundup: Walmart Will Follow Target, Lowe's and TJX
summary: Several big U.S. retailers are reporting earnings this week, offering a glimpse into the spending habits of consumers and the effects of President Trump’s trade war.  Walmart: The retail goliath is due to report at 7 a.m. ET.  Walmart was one of the largest companies to say earlier this year it would pass tariff costs on to consumers and raise prices.

headline: Jackson Hole, Walmart Earnings, Home-Sales Data: Still to Come This Week
summary: This week's set-piece event is the Jackson Hole central-bank gathering in Wyoming, slated for Thursday through Saturday. Investors will tune into Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech for any hints on whether the central bank might kick off interest-rate cuts in September.

headline: Heard on the Street Wednesday Recap: AI Trade Down
summary: Technology stocks sell off again.  Two days don't make a trend, but investors seem to have second thoughts on the market's AI-fueled upswing.  All eight tech companies with market values over $1 trillion closed another day in the red.

headline: Target: Still Wide Of The Mark But Getting Closer
summary: Target is primed for a turnaround. Improving sales, easing headwinds, a 4.6% dividend yield, and undervaluation make TGT stock a strong buy. See more here.
